Content:
A game engine is the backbone of video game development, providing the essential tools and technology needed to create, design, and build video games. Game engines streamline the development process by offering pre-built components for handling graphics, physics, sound, and interactions, allowing game developers to focus more on creativity and gameplay rather than building everything from scratch.

What is a Game Engine?
At its core, a game engine is a software framework designed to simplify the creation of video games. It serves as a reusable platform that provides the basic building blocks developers need to create a game. This includes:

Graphics Rendering: For 2D and 3D visual representation of game worlds.
Physics Simulation: To mimic real-world physics like gravity, collisions, and object interactions.
Scripting: Enables developers to define gameplay rules, character behavior, and events.
Sound Management: Handles sound effects and music within the game.
Artificial Intelligence (AI): To control non-player characters (NPCs) and create dynamic, reactive environments.
Networking: For multiplayer functionalities, managing communication between players.
Title: A Quick Introduction to Game Engines
Author: Sahil Malhotra
